a b s t r a c t
Electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2) to formate is energetically inefficient because high overpotential is required for reduction of CO2 to formate on most traditional catalysts. In this paper, a novel nano-sized Bi-based electrocatalyst deposited on a Cu foil has been synthesized, which can be used as a cathode for electrochemical reduction of CO2 to formate with a low overpotential (0.69 V) and a high selectivity (91.3%). The electrocatalyst can show excellent catalytic performance toward reduction of CO2 which can probably be attributed to the nano-sized structure and the surface oxide layer. The

. Introduction
The concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere has reached an nprecedented level and continues to increase due to fossil fuel ombustion, causing concern about climate change and rising sea evels [1,2]. Converting CO2 and H2O into commodity chemicals sing renewable energy sources could significantly reduce CO2 missions [3–8]. Formic acid and formate are relatively high value ommodity chemicals those are currently synthesized from CO nder high temperature and high pressure. Electrochemical reducion of CO2 to formate powered directly by renewable electricity as attracted much attention in recent years, which is a promising oute to replace the traditional synthesis process [9–12].
Currently, many researchers realized reduction of CO2 to forate in aqueous solutions with high selectivity and high faradaic fficiency, and the most common used electrocatalysts are Sn, In nd Pb metals with high hydrogen overpotentials and low affiniies for CO adsorption [13–15]. Wu et al. reported that the highest aradaic efficiency of 95% can be obtained on a Sn electrode [16].
ori et al. reported that the faradaic efficiency on Sn, In or Pb elecrode can up to 88% [17]. In addition to these traditional metal lectrodes, researchers also developed nanostructured electrodes

and composite materials for reduction of CO2 to formate in water with high selectivity [18–20]. These studies greatly promoted this area, but most of which showed that the absolute overpotentials for reduction of CO2 to formate are too large (>0.95 V) for practical use.
More recently, some electrocatalysts with low overpotentials have been reported. Ruud et al. reported that carbon-supported bimetallic Pd-Pt nanoparticles can reduce CO2 to formate at low overpotential (0.40 V), whereas the faradaic efficiency decreased from 88% to 58% when the electrolysis time increased from 1 to 2 h [21]. Min et al. reported that Pd nanoparticles dispersed on a carbon support can catalyze the reduction of CO2 to formate with high faradaic efficiency (even to 99%) at an overpotential of less than 0.20 V, whereas the Pd catalysts can deactivate due to the formation of CO which poisons formate synthesis at low overpotential [22]. Zhang et al. reported that high surface-area nano-Bi catalyst obtained by reduction of BiOCl nanosheets can catalyze the reduction of CO2 to formate with a high faradaic efficiency (∼92%) at an overpotential around 0.84 V with good stability [23]. The overpotential for the nano-Bi catalyst is a little higher than that of the Pd-based catalyst, but the stability of the Bi-based catalyst is better than that of the Pd-based catalyst, and apparently, the Bi catalyst has lower overpotential than most traditional catalysts. For now, the related studies about the Bi-based catalyst for reduction of CO2 to formate are few, and the reaction mechanism according to the corresponding tafel slope has not been reported. In this work, a novel nano-sized Bi-based catalyst was elecrodeposited on a Cu foil, which was used as a cathode for lectrochemical reduction of CO2 to formate in aqueous solution. he faradaic efficiency and the mechanism for reduction of CO2 to ormate were evaluated. The energy efficiency for producing for-
ate was also studied to evaluate the actual energy consumption.
. Experimental
.1. Preparation of Bi/Cu electrode
A Cu foil (0.1 mm thick) was cleaned with deionized water and thanol ultrasonically, then electropolished in 85% H3PO4 at 4 V sing a Pt counter electrode for 5 min. The polished Cu foil was used s the substrate for electrochemical deposition Bi. The background lectrolyte solution was prepared by mixing choline chloride (99%) nd oxalic acid dihydrate in a mol ratio of 1:1.2, and then heated at 0 ◦C for 30 min until homogeneous colorless solution was formed. hen Bi(NO3)3·5H2O was added to the above solution and its conentration was 0.01 mol L−1. The solution was moderately stirred at 0 ◦C for at least 10 h. Bi was electrodeposited on the Cu substrate n the above solution at 65 ◦C by applying a constant potential of 1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The prepared electrode was rinsed with water nd dried, and marked as Bi/Cu electrode.
.2. Electrochemical experiments
The electrochemical experiments were performed in an undiided three-electrode glass cell. The working electrode was the s-prepared Bi/Cu electrode with the geometric surface area of cm2 or a Bi plate (99.99%, 1 cm2). A Pt plate (2 cm2) or an rxSnyRuzO2/Ti plate (2 cm2, Baoji Yichen Co., China) was chosen as he counter electrode. Unless otherwise stated, the counter elecrode was the Pt plate. An Ag/AgCl electrode (sat. KCl) was chosen he reference electrode. All potential values were in reference to g/AgCl electrode. 40 mL of 0.1 mol L−1 KHCO3 aqueous solution as used as the electrolyte.
Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was carried out using a CHI 60D electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Instruments o., Ltd., China) in N2-saturated or CO2-saturated electrolyte (the lectrolyte was bubbled with N2 or CO2 for 30 min prior to the xperiment). The current density (j) is determined on the geometical area of the electrode. Controlled potential electrolysis was arried out using a LAND CT2001C cell performance-testing instruent (Wuhan Electronics Co., Ltd., China). The electrolyte was aturated with CO2 before the electrolysis reaction, and CO2 gas as continuously aerated at a flow rate of 20 mL min−1 during the lectrolysis process. The total charge passed was 40C. The average urrent density (ja) is expressed as the passed charge (40C here) ivided by the electrolysis time.
.3. Analysis and calculations
Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images and energy disersion spectroscopy (EDS) were taken with a Hitachi S-4800 icroscope at an acceleration voltage of 15 kV. X-ray diffraction attern (XRD) was recorded on a Rigaku SmartLab X-ray diffracometer using Cu K radiation ( = 0.154 nm). The valence state of i on the Bi/Cu electrode surface was quantified by X-ray photolectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi). The liquid products n the electrolyte were directly analyzed by an ion chromatography nstrument (Dionex ICS-900).
The faradaic efficiency for producing formate (f) can be determined by Eq. (1):
f = 2 nF/Q (1) where 2 represents two electrons required for the formation of one molecule of formate from CO2; n is the amount of produced formate; F is Faraday’s constant whose value is 96485C mol−1; and Q is the amount of charge passed across the electrode during the electrolysis (Q = 40C here).
The energy efficiency for producing formate can be calculated by Eq. (2):
Energyefficiency = Estf/Appliedcellpotential (2) where Est represents the standard electromotive force of the cell (Est = −1.43 V here); f is the faradaic efficiency; Applied cell potential is the sum of Est and the overpotential ( ).
3. Results and discussion
The electrolysis experiments were carried out in CO2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 KHCO3 solutions at −1.5 V on the Bi/Cu electrodes which prepared at different deposition times, the obtained faradaic efficiencies for producing formate can be seen in Fig. 1. The highest faradaic efficiency for producing formate (91.3%) is obtained when the deposition time is 25 min and the load weight of the electrodeposits is around 0.41 mg cm−1. Therefore, the Bi/Cu electrodes were prepared by electrodeposition for 25 min in the following experiments.
Fig. 2a gives the morphology of the polished Cu foil substrate, the surface of the polished Cu foil is smooth, and there is no impurity on it (the inset of Fig. 2a). It can be seen from the SEM images of the Bi/Cu electrode (Fig. 2b and c) that the electrodeposits show 3D nano-sized morphological characteristics, and they are densely distributed over the Cu substrate surface. Fig. 2d shows the EDS spectrum of the Bi/Cu electrode and it can be seen that the peak of Bi appears obviously.
Fig. 3 depicts the XRD pattern of the Bi/Cu electrode. The peaks at 43.3, 50.5 and 74.2◦ are assigned to (111), (200) and (220) planes of the Cu substrate (PDF 4–836), respectively. The peaks at 27.2, 38.0 and 39.7◦ are assigned to (012), (104) and (110) planes of the deposited Bi (PDF 44–1246), respectively. It indicates that Bi has been deposited on the Cu substrate surface successfully, which is consistent with the result of Fig. 2d.
Fig. 4 shows the high-resolution XPS spectrum recorded for Bi 4f region of the Bi/Cu electrode. It can be seen that the Bi 4f7/2 spectrum of the Bi/Cu electrode can fit to two components at 159.4 and

In this study, the oxiized Bi on the surface of the Bi/Cu electrode may also be beneficial or CO2 reduction. The electrolysis experiments were performed on the Bi/Cu elecrode in CO2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 KHCO3 solution applying a onstant potential in the range from −1.4 to −1.7 V, and the results re shown in Fig. 5. Our previous work showed that although the eduction product of formate can re-oxidize on the anode, its oxidaion rate is very slow when its concentration is below 0.01 mol L−1 28]. In this work, the electrolysis experiments were terminated hen the total charge reached to 40C (equivalent to 0.005 mol L−1 ormate if the faradaic efficiency is 100%), thus the faradaic effiiency cannot be influenced by the re-oxidization of the formate on he anode. Fig. 5a shows the variations of the electrolysis current ensity with electrolysis time during the electrochemical reduction f CO2 at different electrolysis potentials. The electrolysis current ensity increases as the electrolysis potential decreases from −1.4 o −1.7 V. As shown in Fig. 5b, the average current density increases
as the electrolysis potential decreases. As the electrolysis potential decreases, the faradaic efficiency for producing formate increases; when the electrolysis potential decreases to −1.5 V, the faradaic efficiency can reach to 91.3%; as the electrolysis potential decreases further, the faradaic efficiency begins to stabilize at around 95% (Fig. 5b).
We repeated the electroreduction of CO2 using the same Bi/Cu electrode for 3 times (the total electrolysis time was around 10 h), after that, the faradaic efficiency for producing formate decreased to 83.4%. From Fig. 6, we can see that after a long electrolysis, nanosized Bi on the Bi/Cu electrode aggregated a little compared to the morphology of the Bi/Cu electrode before electrolysis in Fig. 2c. This result indicated that the stability of the Bi-based electrode should be further improved.
Fig. 7a illustrates the LSV curves of the Bi plate electrode and the Bi/Cu electrode in N2-saturated or CO2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 KHCO3 solutions. Generally, in N2-saturated system only reduction of H2O (H2 evolution reaction) occurs; while in CO2-saturated system, both the CO2 reduction reaction and the H2 evolution reaction (as a competing reaction) take place. We can see there is no big difference of the curves between the Bi plate electrode and the Bi/Cu electrode in N2-saturated system. Whereas in CO2-saturated system, the Bi/Cu electrode has obviously bigger reduction current density than the Bi plate electrode, which can be mainly attributed to that the prepared Bi/Cu electrode with the large superficial area has better electrocatalytic performance for CO2 reduction than the Bi plate.
We also carried out the electrolysis experiment on the Bi plate electrode at −1.5 V in CO2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 KHCO3 solution, the electrolysis results are shown in Fig. 7b. It can be found that, for the Bi plate electrode and the Bi/Cu electrode, the faradaic efficiencies for producing formate are 15.2% and 91.3%, respectively, the results are consistent with the LSV results; the average current densities for electrolysis are 1.91 and 3.08 mA cm−2, respectively; the production rates for electrochemical reduction of CO2 to formate are 5.41 and 52.4 mol h−1, respectively. For the Bi/Cu electrode, the average current density is higher than that of the Bi plate electrode, and the faradaic efficiency and the production rate of formate are substantially higher than those of the Bi plate electrode, which are six and almost ten times those of the Bi plate electrode, respectively. The highest faradaic efficiency on Sn-based electrode was obtained at the potential of around −1.8 V vs. Ag/AgCl in many works [14,18,20,27,28]. In this work, the optimal electrolysis potential for reduction of CO2 to formate on Bi/Cu electrode is −1.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl. Compared to the Sn electrode, the electrolysis potential of the Bi/Cu electrode is obviously less negative. Fig. 9 is the qualitative reaction scheme for reduction of CO2 to formic acid on the Sn electrode and the Bi/Cu electrode. The formic acid can dissociate to formate in the neutral electrolyte [31]. . Conclusions
Bi/Cu electrode has been prepared by electrodepositing a Biased electrocatalyst on a Cu foil substrate. SEM, EDS and XRD are sed to analyze the morphology and the structure of the Bi/Cu elecrode, and the results indicate that nano-sized Bi is loaded on the Cu ubstrate successfully. A mixed valence of Bi3+ and Bi0 is observed n the surface of the Bi/Cu electrode by XPS analysis. The Bi/Cu lectrode is used as the cathode for electrocatalytic reduction of O2. Faradaic efficiency for producing formate is influenced by the eposition time, and it increases as the deposition time increases.
When the Bi/Cu electrode is prepared by electrodeposition for 5 min, the load weight of the deposited Bi is around 0.41 mg cm−1, nd the faradaic efficiency can reach to 91.3% at the electrolysis otential of −1.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The Bi/Cu electrode shows high atalytic activity for CO2 reduction compared to the Bi plate elecrode. When an IrxSnyRuzO2/Ti electrode is used as the anode, the nergy efficiency for reduction of CO2 to formate on the Bi/Cu elecrode can reach to 50%. This work indicates that the prepared Bi/Cu lectrode has excellent electrocatalytic performance for electrohemical reduction of CO2 to formate.

metadata.abstractText: Electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2) to formate is energetically inefficient because high overpotential is required for reduction of CO2 to formate on most traditional catalysts. In this paper, a novel nano-sized Bi-based electrocatalyst deposited on a Cu foil has been synthesized, which can be used as a cathode for electrochemical reduction of CO2 to formate with a low overpotential (0.69 V) and a high selectivity (91.3%). The electrocatalyst can show excellent catalytic performance toward reduction of CO2 which can probably be attributed to the nano-sized structure and the surface oxide layer. The
